name: Azure Tenant Compromise – Containment
description:
# ☁️ Azure Tenant Compromise – Containment

---

## 🎯 Usage

Quickly regain control of the compromised Azure tenant by:

* Removing malicious access and applications
* Cleaning up accounts, configurations, and workloads
* Deploying durable measures to prevent re-intrusion

---

## ⚙️ Prerequisites before starting

* 👥 Staff available with administrative rights on the Azure tenant
* 🔑 Valid, uncompromised admin account (ideally Global Administrator)
* 👥 Technical support quickly mobilizable if the IS is managed

---

## 📌 Objective

Detail containment measures and possible actions by compromise type:

* **Case 1**: Compromise of a Microsoft 365 or Entra ID account
* **Case 2**: Compromise of a Microsoft Azure Entra enterprise application
* **Case 3**: Compromise of an Azure resource
* **Case 4**: Unwanted content relay
* **Case 5**: Information leak

---

## 📄 Resource

👉 [Full reflex sheet – INTERCERT-FR](https://www.intercert-france.fr/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/fichereflexe-compromissiontenantazure-endiguement.pdf)

tasks.title: Case 3: Compromise of an Azure resource
tasks.description:
## 🎯 Objective

Isolate compromised Azure resources and revoke associated credentials to stop malicious activity, limit propagation, and secure service continuity.

---

## 📌 Actions

* **Identify the compromised Azure resource and apply appropriate isolation**:

  * **VM**: disconnect NIC, apply restrictive NSG, or pause the VM
  * **PaaS (App Service, Azure Function)**: temporarily disable the service, block external access via IP restrictions
  * **Storage Account**: disable public access, regenerate *storage keys*, apply restrictive network firewall
* Confirm effectiveness of isolation through absence of new alerts (blocked traffic, no more EDR/AV alerts, Microsoft Defender for Cloud signals)

---

* **Revoke compromised credentials linked to Azure resources**

  * Revoke and renew:

    * Keys/secrets in **Azure Key Vault**
    * Access tokens for **APIs or external services**
    * Passwords of local technical accounts (VM, services)
  * Update application configurations to reference new secured credentials
  * Verify old credentials are no longer usable (practical tests + log analysis)

---

## ✅ Deliverables

* Compromised credentials revoked, new ones deployed in production
* Old credentials added as observables for tracking and traceability
* Compromised resources isolated and malicious traffic blocked
* Logs/alerts before-after and configuration captures added as observables
* Actions documented in the **activities** of this task

tasks.title: Case 4: Undesirable content relay
tasks.description:
## 🎯 Objective

Restore and strengthen compromised anti-spam and anti-spoofing configurations to stop ongoing abuse, block email-borne threats, and reduce the risk of recurrence.

---

### 📌 Actions

* Restore compromised anti-spam configuration

  * Log in to the allow/block list management portal:
    [https://security.microsoft.com/tenantAllowBlockList](https://security.microsoft.com/tenantAllowBlockList)
  * Remove **illegitimate domains** and **addresses** added by the attacker.

---

* Strengthen anti-spam configuration to prevent recurrence

  * Apply stricter policies for **high-risk users** (VIPs, technical accounts, executives).
  * Log in to preset security policies portal:
    [https://security.microsoft.com/presetSecurityPolicies](https://security.microsoft.com/presetSecurityPolicies)
  * Create a **Strict Protection** policy.
  * Enable **systematic quarantine** for suspicious emails.
  * Log in to the anti-spam configuration portal:
    [https://security.microsoft.com/antispam](https://security.microsoft.com/antispam)
  * Enable **admin notifications** for suspicious bulk send/receive activities.

---

* Restore compromised anti-spoofing policy

  * Log in to anti-phishing management:
    [https://security.microsoft.com/antiphishing](https://security.microsoft.com/antiphishing)
  * Review the **anti-phishing policy** settings in Microsoft 365 Defender.
  * Select the **active rule** and validate the following entries:

    * Manage `[x] senders`
    * Manage `[x] custom domain(s)`
    * Manage `[x] approved sender(s) and domain(s)`

---

✅ **Deliverables**

* List of removed malicious domains/addresses.
* Reinforced anti-spam policies applied.
* Restored and validated anti-spoofing policy.
* Malicious domains and senders added as observables.
* Actions logged in the **activities** of this task.

tasks.title: Case 1: Compromise of a Microsoft 365 or Entra ID account
tasks.description:
## 🎯 Objective

Regain control of the compromised account and prevent reuse by the attacker.

---

## 📌 Actions

* **Reset account passwords**

  * Sign in to [Entra ID](https://entra.microsoft.com)
  * Go to **Users > Active users**
  * Select the account → **Reset password** (twice to get a temporary password)

---

* **Revoke active sessions**

  * [Entra ID](https://entra.microsoft.com) → **Active users** → Select the account → **Revoke sessions**

---

* **Disable the account if necessary**

  * [Entra ID](https://entra.microsoft.com) → **Active users** → Select the account → **Edit properties**
  * **Settings** tab → uncheck *Account enabled* → **Save**

---

* **Require MFA re-registration**

  * [Entra ID](https://entra.microsoft.com) → **Active users** → Select the account → **Authentication methods**
  * Click **Require re-register MFA** → **OK**

---

* **Harden conditional access policy**

  * Block malicious IP addresses / apply geographic filtering
  * [Entra ID](https://entra.microsoft.com) → **Protection > Conditional access** → Create a new policy

---

* **Revoke illegitimate Entra ID roles**

  * [Entra ID](https://entra.microsoft.com) → **Active users** → Select the account → **Assigned roles**
  * Remove illegitimate roles

---

## ✅ Deliverables

* Compromised account secured (password reset, MFA re-registered, sessions revoked)
* Conditional access and roles reviewed
* Actions documented in the **activities** of this task

tasks.title: Case 5: Information leakage
tasks.description:
## 🎯 Objective

Remove all persistence and compromise mechanisms in Exchange Online (rules, delegations, legacy protocols, unauthorized extensions) in order to block data exfiltration, secure mailboxes, and restore a healthy configuration.

---

## 📌 Actions

* Remove illegitimate inbox rules

  * Open a PowerShell console.
    Installing the **ExchangeOnlineManagement** PowerShell module is a prerequisite and can be done with:

  ```powershell
  Install-Module ExchangeOnlineManagement -Scope CurrentUser
  ```

  * Connect to Exchange Online PowerShell (replace `<admin@yourdomain.com>`):

  ```powershell
  Connect-ExchangeOnline -UserPrincipalName <admin@yourdomain.com> -ShowProgress $true
  ```

  * List inbox rules of a user (replace `<user@yourdomain.com>`):

  ```powershell
  Get-InboxRule -Mailbox "<user@yourdomain.com>"
  ```

  * Remove illegitimate rules (replace `<RuleName>`):

  ```powershell
  Remove-InboxRule -Mailbox "<user@yourdomain.com>" -Identity "<RuleName>"
  ```

---

* Remove illegitimate transport rules

  * Connect to the **Exchange Admin Center**:
    [https://admin.exchange.microsoft.com/#/transportrules](https://admin.exchange.microsoft.com/#/transportrules)
  * Identify suspicious rules (external forwarding, hidden copy).
  * Disable or delete illegitimate rules.
  * Restore a clean configuration if a rule export exists.

---

* Disable direct authentication on shared mailboxes (via IMAP, POP, SMTP Auth, MAPI, OWA)

  * Identify all shared mailboxes with direct authentication enabled.
  * Open a PowerShell console.
    Installing the **ExchangeOnlineManagement** module is a prerequisite:

  ```powershell
  Install-Module ExchangeOnlineManagement -Scope CurrentUser
  ```

  * List shared mailboxes with direct authentication enabled:

  ```powershell
  Get-Mailbox -RecipientTypeDetails SharedMailbox | Get-CASMailbox
  ```

  * Disable direct access (IMAP, POP, MAPI, OWA) if enabled (replace `<Mailbox>`):

  ```powershell
  Set-CASMailbox -Identity "<Mailbox>" -MAPIEnabled $false
  ```

  * Retain access only via delegation on an authenticated user account.

---

* Disable legacy protocols (IMAP, POP, SMTP Auth)

  * Open a PowerShell console.
    Prerequisite: install the **ExchangeOnlineManagement** module:

  ```powershell
  Install-Module ExchangeOnlineManagement -Scope CurrentUser
  ```

  * Check allowed protocols at tenant and user level:

  ```powershell
  Get-CASMailbox | Where-Object {$_.PopEnabled -eq $true -or $_.ImapEnabled -eq $true}
  ```

  * Disable obsolete protocols unless strictly required (replace `<user>`):

  ```powershell
  Set-CASMailbox -Identity "<user>" -PopEnabled $false -ImapEnabled $false -SmtpClientAuthenticationDisabled $true
  ```

  * Monitor whether accounts are still attempting to use these protocols (Defender alerts).

---

* Remove unauthorized attachment extensions

  * Open a PowerShell console.
    Prerequisite: install the **ExchangeOnlineManagement** module:

  ```powershell
  Install-Module ExchangeOnlineManagement -Scope CurrentUser
  ```

  * Connect to Exchange Online PowerShell (replace `<admin@yourdomain.com>`):

  ```powershell
  Connect-ExchangeOnline -UserPrincipalName <admin@yourdomain.com> -ShowProgress $true
  ```

  * Modify Exchange Online anti-malware policies. For example, block `.exe`, `.js`, `.vbs`, `.scr`:

  ```powershell
  New-TransportRule -Name "Block Executable Attachments" -AttachmentExtensionMatchesWords "exe","js","vbs","scr" -RejectMessageReasonText "Executable files are blocked for security reasons." -Enabled $true
  ```

  * Add additional rules to block extensions specifically used during the incident.
  * Define and monitor alerts to identify any compromised accounts not yet detected.

---

* Remove illegitimate mailbox delegations

  * Connect to the **Exchange Admin Center**:
    [https://admin.cloud.microsoft/exchange#/mailboxes](https://admin.cloud.microsoft/exchange#/mailboxes)
  * Select the mailbox account.
  * Remove illegitimate delegations for:

    * Send As
    * Send on Behalf
    * Full Access (Read and Manage)
  * Connect to Exchange Online PowerShell (replace `<admin@yourdomain.com>`):

  ```powershell
  Connect-ExchangeOnline -UserPrincipalName <admin@yourdomain.com> -ShowProgress $true
  ```

  * Verify remaining delegations and restore a legitimate configuration if necessary.

---

## ✅ Deliverables

* Target addresses added as observables.
* List of rules disabled/removed.
* List of secured mailboxes.
* List of blocked extensions.
* List of delegations removed.
* Trace all actions performed in the **activities** of this task.

tasks.title: Case 2: Compromise of a Microsoft Azure Entra enterprise application
tasks.description:
### 🎯 Objective

Isolate and secure compromised or malicious applications in Entra ID.

---

## 📌 Actions

* **Disable sign-in to the compromised or malicious application**

  * Evaluate business impact vs. security risk first.
  * Sign in to **[https://entra.microsoft.com](https://entra.microsoft.com)**.
  * Go to **Applications > Enterprise applications**.

    * Select the compromised application (remove filters if needed).
  * Disable the application: in **Properties**, set *Enabled for user sign-in?* to **No**.

    * Malicious app: delete after investigation.
    * Compromised app: recreate/configure a new secure app, then delete the old one after investigation.
  * Explore hardening options:

    * Conditional Access for service identities
    * Application risk policies

---

* **Review access for a compromised app not disabled**

  * Sign in to **[https://entra.microsoft.com](https://entra.microsoft.com)** > Enterprise applications.
  * Select the compromised app > **Permissions** > **Review permissions**.
  * Select "**This app is malicious and I am compromised**."
  * Run the 3 proposed PowerShell scripts (after installing the `Microsoft.Graph` module with `Install-Module Microsoft.Graph`) to quickly clean authentication configuration:

    1. Remove affected users
    2. Invalidate refresh tokens
    3. Revoke all permissions
  * In **Properties**: require user assignment
  * In **Permissions**: revoke illegitimate admin and user consents
  * In **Users and groups**: remove illegitimate affected users

---

* **Reset certificates and secrets of a compromised app not disabled**

  * Sign in to **[https://entra.microsoft.com](https://entra.microsoft.com)** > **Applications > App registrations > Certificates & Secrets**
  * Delete compromised certificates and secrets
  * Recreate only legitimate certificates/secrets if needed

---

* **Remove illegitimate Entra ID roles from a compromised app**

  * Sign in to **[https://entra.microsoft.com](https://entra.microsoft.com)** > **Roles and administrators**
  * Download assignments to quickly identify illegitimate roles
  * Remove the app from compromised roles

---

* **Restore legitimate roles & administrators configuration**

  * Identify suspicious recent changes
  * Sign in to **[https://entra.microsoft.com](https://entra.microsoft.com)** > **Enterprise applications > Roles and administrators**
  * Restore original legitimate configuration

---

* **Restore the legitimate owner of the compromised app**

  * Identify suspicious changes to owners/admins
  * Sign in to **[https://entra.microsoft.com](https://entra.microsoft.com)** > **App registrations** > select the app
  * Reassign the legitimate owner
  * Immediately notify the restored owner to review permissions

---

* **Enforce explicit administrator consent**

  * Sign in to **[https://entra.microsoft.com](https://entra.microsoft.com)** > **Enterprise applications > Consent and permissions**
  * In **User consent settings**:

    * Allow only for verified publisher apps and low-impact apps
  * In **Admin consent settings**:

    * Enable "*Users can request admin consent*"
    * Define groups or roles authorized to review requests
    * Save changes

---

## ✅ Deliverables

* Compromised app isolated/removed
* Compromised certificates and secrets revoked
* All actions documented in the **activities** of this task
